feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 5 at 4:03AM PST until March 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of up to one inch mainly south of Redmond.
* WHERE...Central Oregon.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PST this morning.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 6:03AM CST by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
At 603 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8 miles west of Morrill, or 16 miles south of Rusk, moving east at 10 mph.
HAZARD...Half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Weches.

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT NORTH CENTRAL HOUSTON COUNTY THROUGH 630 AM CST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 6:02AM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
At 602 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Lone Star to near Ore City to near Hallsville. Movement was east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Marshall, Hallsville, Daingerfield, Jefferson, Hughes Springs, Lone Star, Ore City, Woodlawn, Jenkins, Berea, Harleton, Cedar Springs, Fairview, Avinger, Scottsville, Lassater, Nesbitt, Holly Springs, Pruett, and Center Point.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Camp; Morris; Cass; Upshur; Marion; Harrison

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT WESTERN MARION...SOUTHWESTERN CASS...NORTHWESTERN HARRISON...NORTHEASTERN UPSHUR...SOUTHERN MORRIS AND SOUTHEASTERN CAMP COUNTIES THROUGH 630 AM CST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 5:56AM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary: A band of snow is expected to lift northward into the area this morning, bringing a chance for brief but heavy snowfall rates. Visibility could be sharply reduced at times as this band moves across the region. Most areas will see around 1 inch of snow or less, with isolated higher totals to the south and west of Valley City.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued March 5 at 5:55AM CST until March 5 at 6:15AM CST by NWS Tulsa OK
entry.summary:
At 555 AM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Fern, moving east at 30 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
Locations in or near the path include... Fern... Bidville... Piney...

cap:parameter.value: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 615 AM CST FOR NORTHWESTERN FRANKLIN AND NORTHEASTERN CRAWFORD COUNTIES

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 5 at 5:55AM CST until March 5 at 8:00AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
FFWLZK
The National Weather Service in Little Rock has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southeastern Newton County in north central Arkansas... Southwestern Searcy County in north central Arkansas...
* Until 800 AM CST.
* At 555 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain have fallen. Rainfall has mostly come to an end but flash flooding is likely ongoing.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Moore... Witts Spring... Bohannon... Marsena... Imo... Kay... Watts... Ben Hur... Tilly... Lurton... Cowell... Canaan... Deer...

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 8:00 AM CST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 8:00 AM CST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

Locations impacted include... Crockett, Kennard, and Latexo.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 5:49AM CST by NWS Tulsa OK
entry.summary:
At 549 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 3 miles north of Fern to 3 miles northwest of Dyer to 2 miles northeast of Fort Smith. Movement was east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down small tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations in or near the path include... Fort Smith... Van Buren... Mountainburg... Alma... Arkoma... Mulberry... Dyer... Winslow... Chester... Rudy... Cass... Lake Fort Smith... Fern... Kibler... Concord... Jethro... Shibley... Bidville... Combs... Locke...
This includes the following highways, Interstate 40 in Arkansas between mile markers 3 and 29. Interstate 540 between mile markers 1 and 9. Interstate 49 between mile markers 22 and 39.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued March 5 at 5:48AM CST until March 5 at 6:45AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
SVRFWD
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Northeastern Freestone County in central Texas... Anderson County in central Texas...
* Until 645 AM CST.
* At 547 AM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located 9 miles northeast of Fairfield Lake, or 17 miles northeast of Fairfield, moving southeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Damage to vehicles is possible.
* This severe thunderstorm will be near... Palestine around 620 AM CST.
Other locations impacted by this severe thunderstorm include Johnson, Brushy Creek, Bradford, Bois D'arc, Blackfoot, Cayuga, Pert, Yard, Springfield, and Crystal Lake.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 6:46AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
At 645 AM, traffic cameras showed patchy dense fog reducing visibility to one half mile or less had developed northern Orange, northern Lake, and Seminole counties. This includes parts of highways 429 and 46.
Drivers should prepare to encounter rapid visibility reductions. When driving in fog, slow down, use only low beam headlights, and leave extra following distance between your vehicle and the one in front of you.

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Dense Fog Occurring in Portions of Orange, Lake, and Seminole Counties

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 5 at 3:39AM PST until March 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning above 1500 feet, heavy wet snow. Additional snow accumulations of up 2 to 5 inches. For the Winter Weather Advisory above 500 feet, wet snow. Additional snow accumulations of up to 1 to 3 inches.
* WHERE...For the winter storm warning, elevations above 1500 feet in central Douglas County and eastern Douglas County foothills. This includes the passes on I-5, the Tiller-Trail highway, and portions of highway 138 east of Steamboat. For the winter weather advisory, elevations above 500 feet in the Umpqua Basin.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 10 AM PST Tuesday. For the Winter Storm Warning, until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow is being observed in Roseburg, so the snow levels are varying from 500 feet up to 2000 feet in this zone. Heavy showers could pull down snow levels lower than anticipated.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON ABOVE 1500 FEET... ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PST THIS MORNING ABOVE 500 FEET

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 5 at 3:39AM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 7 to 13 inches in the Cascades and 3 to 6 inches in the foothills. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Douglas County Foothills and South Central Oregon Cascades, including highways 62, 230, 138, and 58, Diamond Lake, Crater Lake, and Union Creek.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snowfall rates will be highest tonight. Travel could be impossible in the high Cascades.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Douglas County Foothills; South Central Oregon Cascades

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 5 at 3:39AM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow above 3500 feet. Additional snow accumulations 1 to 4 inches with up to 9 inches possible in the highest elevations. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Elevations above 3500 feet in north central and southeast Siskiyou County. This includes portions of Highway 97 and the communities of Bray and Tennant.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: North Central and Southeast Siskiyou County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST THIS AFTERNOON ABOVE 3500 FEET

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 5 at 3:39AM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow occurring. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 9 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph. For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Additional snow accumulations of up to 5 inches.
* WHERE...For the Winter Storm Warning, northern sections of Lake and Klamath County. This includes much of highway 97, portions of highways 31, 140, and 395, and the communities of Christmas Valley, Chemult, Chiloquin, Lakeview, and Valley Falls. The Winter Weather Advisory includes Modoc Point and Klamath Falls, Crescent, Silver Lake, Fort Rock, and Paisley.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County; Central and Eastern Lake County

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 5 at 5:36AM CST until March 5 at 11:00AM CST by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
FFWILX
The National Weather Service in Lincoln has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Northern Sangamon County in central Illinois... Southeastern Morgan County in west central Illinois...
* Until 1100 AM CST.
* At 535 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Springfield, Alexander, Sherman, Riverton, South Jacksonville, Williamsville, New Berlin, Murrayville, Woodson, Dawson, Abraham Lincoln Capital Airport, Illinois State Fairgrounds, Jerome, Leland Grove, Grandview, Spaulding, Clear Lake, Curran and Berlin.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 5 at 6:10AM EST until March 6 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Lexington, Richland and Calhoun Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Carolina Eastman.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 115.0 feet, Flooding occurs in low lying areas of the Carolina Eastman Facility and at the Congaree National Park.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:06 AM EST Tuesday the stage was 115.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 114.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:06 AM EST Tuesday was 117.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this morning and continue falling to 112.1 feet Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 115.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calhoun, SC; Lexington, SC; Richland, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 5 at 6:10AM EST until March 7 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Lexington, Richland and Calhoun Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree National Park-Gadsden.
* WHEN...Until Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek. At 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the river become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake overlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet the river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:00 AM EST Tuesday the stage was 16.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 5:00 AM EST Tuesday was 16.9 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 16.4 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow morning to 13.8 feet early Thursday afternoon. It will rise to 14.7 feet early Saturday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL THURSDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 3:44AM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
A low pressure system will bring an area of snow across south central North Dakota through this morning. While most locations are only expected to see 1 to 3 inches of accumulation, localized amounts as high as 4 to 6 inches will be possible. Snow amounts could vary greatly over short distances, and the exact location of the heaviest snow will be difficult to anticipate until it starts falling. Where snow is heaviest, snow-covered roads and poor visibility can be expected.
Be sure to check the latest forecast information and road conditions before heading out on the morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Morton; Burleigh; Kidder; Stutsman; Grant; Sioux; Emmons; Logan; La Moure; McIntosh; Dickey

cap:parameter.value: LOCALIZED HEAVY SNOW POSSIBLE THROUGH THIS MORNING

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 5 at 2:39AM MST until March 6 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FOR THE NORTHEAST PLAINS FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING DUE TO GUSTY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Good mixing of stronger southwest winds aloft, combined with very dry and relatively warm conditions will bring several hours of critical fire weather conditions to the Northeast Highlands Wednesday afternoon to early Wednesday evening.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Highlands (Zone 123) from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest to west 20 to 25 mph with occasional gusts to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...9 to 14 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 5 at 3:17AM CST by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
entry.summary: Pockets of dense fog with visibility of 1/4 mile are occurring across the Rio Grande, Southern Edwards Plateau and east of Interstate 35. If traveling early this morning, be alert for rapidly changing visibility, slow down, and allow for extra travel time. If this trend continues and more reports with low visibilities come in, a Dense Fog Advisory will likely be issued. Visibility is forecast to improve between 9 and 10 am.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 5 at 3:46AM EST by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Washington and New London Counties.
For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Pawcatuck River at Westerly.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Lowland flooding is anticipated from Hopkinton downriver through Westerly, Stonington and New Stonington. Lowest lying homes along Hiscox Road in Westerly are inundated by floodwaters. Along Route 3, flooding occurs at homes in French Village in Hopkinton. Follow the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so. Floodwaters may inundate Route 49 by the North Stonington and Stonington town line.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EST Tuesday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM EST Tuesday was 7.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate above flood stage with a maximum value of 8.8 feet Thursday evening. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog.
* WHERE...Aransas Islands County.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM CST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility.

cap:parameter.value: DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM CST TUESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 9:29PM CST by NWS Corpus Christi TX
entry.summary:
Areas of fog will develop tonight through Tuesday morning across South Texas. Expect visibilities generally 1 mile or less with a few locations seeing visibilities 1/4 mile or less at times.
Use caution if traveling as visibility may change rapidly in a short amount of time. Use low beam headlights and leave extra distance between your vehicle and others on the road.
entry.cap:areaDesc: La Salle; McMullen; Live Oak; Bee; Webb; Duval

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 9:02PM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...Texas...
Sabine River Near Deweyville
For the Sabine River...including Burkeville, Bon Wier, Deweyville, Orange...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued as needed. Tuesday evening at 915 PM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sabine River near Deweyville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 24.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM CST Monday the stage was 24.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:45 PM CST Monday was 24.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 24.4 feet. - Flood stage is 24.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beauregard, LA; Calcasieu, LA; Newton, TX; Orange, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 5:51PM AKST until March 5 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow with low visibility and wind chills to 50 below. Additional snow accumulations of up to one inch. Visibility one half mile or less at times. East winds gusting to 40 mph.
* WHERE...Northwest Arctic Coast.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult. Areas of blowing snow will cause reduces visibility. Snow drifts will form. Wind chills to 50 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued March 4 at 5:51PM AKST until March 5 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions occuring. Additional snow accumulations of two inches. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph. Wind chills 45 below.
* WHERE...Western Arctic Coast.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be difficult. Areas of blowing snow will reduce visibility to near zero at times. Snow drifts will form. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 45 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Blizzard conditions will continue through Tuesday evening. Very cold wind chills may continue into Wednesday.

cap:parameter.value: BLIZZARD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 4 at 5:51PM AKST until March 6 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills to 50 below zero. East winds 15 to 25 mph.
* WHERE...Northern Arctic Coast, Central Beaufort Sea Coast and Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Very cold wind chills will continue into Wednesday. Wind chills will briefly become less severe Tuesday afternoon.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Low visibility in blowing snow will continue through Tuesday evening. Very cold wind chills may continue into Wednesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Arctic Coast; Central Beaufort Sea Coast; Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast

cap:parameter.value: WIND CHILL ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 8:37PM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following bayou in Louisiana...
Bodcau Bayou At Bayou Bodcau Lake affecting Webster and Bossier Parishes.
For the Bodcau Bayou...including Bayou Bodcau Lake...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Bodcau Bayou at Bayou Bodcau Lake.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM CST Monday the stage was 174.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 171.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:00 PM CST Monday was 175.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 172.4 feet Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 172.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 4 at 3:11PM HST until March 6 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WINTER STORM WARNING FOR THE BIG ISLAND SUMMITS...
* WHAT...Periods of freezing rain, mainly at night, leading to significant icing. Additional ice accumulations of around one half of an inch.
* WHERE...Big Island Summits.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM HST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be impossible.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM HST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 4 at 12:22PM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches at elevations above 4000 feet, locally up to 2 feet at highest peaks. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County, Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County and Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels around 3000 to 4000 feet through this evening, rising to 4000 to 5500 feet by Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST TUESDAY
